pros: Great co-workers, supportive management, some room for growth depending on the department, benefits available for full-time only

You can be a great server with exceptional customer service but if you have only been there one year or less and work part time you will not be making any tips to get excited about. The raises are pitiful as well. This is why they can't hang on to good help. It is unfortunate because it is a great place to work but you'll always be dirt poor.

I have been working for this company for over 10 yrs, and I love it. The company does follow its guiding principle in taking care of its residents and staff. There is every opportunity for personal development, growth, and supportive leadership. In addition, the company have great benefits.

I highly recommend working for this company if you are diligent and hardworking.
cons: I can't think of any.

job_title: General Laborer in Los Gatos, CA
pros: Residents, residents residents residents residents
cons: Management management management management management

review_title: You owe it to yourself to NOT work for Covia.
pros: You get to help people that need help.
cons:
Crap job, crap pay, crap benefits, and no opportunities for advancement. The pay and benefits are absolutely awful and are not enough to support yourself in the Bay Area. Unlike senior management, who are quite generous with themselves, lower-level staff earn peanuts ($16.50 per hour). Covia has more than enough money to give all their employees a competitive wage, but they most assuredly don't. Turnover is extremely high and everybody is eyeing something better elsewhere.

By the way, I think it is pretty telling that they have some useless PR flack trolling Glassdoor to put out fires by all the many disgruntled employees. They are more concerned about their image than they are with treating their employees fairly. Maybe they could cut her position and distribute her pay to employees that actually provide a meaningful and worthwhile service.

Finally, there are other very negative consequences for Covia not providing all their employees a competitive wage. If morale is low and turnover is just another 'cost of doing business' for executive management, ultimately the patients and clients suffer the most. You can't count on consistent, high-quality service from people that feel their employer is blatantly shortchanging them. That's not something you can just paper over with PR and bought-and-sold, self-serving employee satisfaction questionnaires.

In short, anyone considering working at Covia owes it to themselves to pass on it. There are far greener pastures elsewhere.

review_title: Senior management played favorites and did not communicate. The company is led by all white leadership
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: The holiday events that HR put on
cons: Senior leadership and the CEO

review_title: Lovely facility, kind colleagues, volatile corporate leadership
pros: I worked at a lovely facility, and the professional relationships were largely smooth and cordial—focused on caring for the community.
cons:
During the time I was there, a corporate HR officer effectively strongly hinted to the hundreds of hourly support staff that they should vote to elect the organization among the best places to work in the Bay Area. They're apparently playing a numbers game to win the award—there are a lot of hourly employees.

Also, I was there during a time of turmoil between the corporate offices and residents and staff at the San Francisco location. A painful time all around. It seemed, in part, personal, though I don't know for certain. It was ugly and uncomfortable. 

This in and of itself is not unusual cycles in organizations. But there were a couple of events that seemed gratuitous shows of rage by corporate leadership. Maybe they've matured since then?

review_title: The Pay = Slap in the Face
pros: You get to help people and much of the staff is pleasant to work with. As far as workplaces go, there isn't a ton of drama or dysfunction.
cons: If you are an entry- or even mid-level worker, the amount they pay you is an insult. (And it's not like the executive-level employees share the burden.) The raises are a complete, nasty joke and you even have to "time-in" and "time-out" instead of just getting paid a salary like a normal employee. It's almost like having a high school job that way. There are also no real opportunities for advancement. It's a dead end.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: It can feel positive to help seniors in need, but that's around the gist of it.
cons:
Compensation - Quite convinced s this company does not understand what the word competitive means. Competitive perhaps with the national average for most positions in a place where housing is 200-300% more expensive. When you have a person making well over 100k a year telling you they want to improve benefits and make you all feel appreciated yet refuse to acknowledge pay is far less than competitors and at the same time complain about corporate budgets morale is damaged.
Turnover - High mostly due to above issue: but it's going to take a lot of these honest assessments before they get the idea.
Best Places to Work - Consistently places in a payed contest by a local newspaper: All for the purpose of  recruiting more applicants, enhancing brand, retaining talent, etc. etc.: All while attempting to avoid compensating employees fairly.

review_title: Good culture with room to grow
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Overall, very positive and supportive culture and a caring community with no dead weight and lots of opportunities to celebrate and play. Senior leadership works hard to make sure people are thanked for their contributions. Pay and benefits are good -- with a pension plan!
cons: There's not a strong tradition of career development, so it is easy to get stuck in place. Senior Leadership tends to take on responsibilities rather than train others to do it.

Although the company will pay for "English as a second language" class, the employees choose not to take it as at their age, they feel it is a waste of time.   Makes it difficult to communicate and comprehend, as an em

pros: Wonderful co-workers in the community I worked for. Everyone was positive and supportive of each other. If there was ever an issue, management will address it in a very respectful way.
